When a subject passionate me I can think longer, harder and much more creatively than others. I might be less efficient but the unique and creative solution that I will be able to find out of the box will make you forget about it. 

Best regards

Theodore Bedos

12/08/2023, 09:20 - Théodore Bedos: Hi Samuel,

I trust you're having a pleasant day.

Regrettably, we find ourselves in a situation where we're a bit disappointed with the current state of the Airbnb. Our intention in reaching out is to ensure that you're informed about the concerns we've encountered during our stay:

Limited Building Access: Given that our reservation was made for two guests, it's proving inconvenient that only one guest can access the building. Since our schedules might not always align, having both of us able to enter and exit independently would be more convenient.

Room Cleanliness: It appears that the room hasn't met our expectations in terms of cleanliness, which we value highly. We've taken some photos to help illustrate the issue (attached for reference).

Bed Linen Missing: We've noticed that the duvet lacks a sheet, which is an essential component for a comfortable stay.

Mattress Comfort: The comfort of the bed has proven to be quite challenging, as the mattress is exceptionally hard and not conducive to a good night's sleep.

We'd like to emphasize that we appreciate your efforts as a host, and we believe you've been a welcoming presence during our stay. We also understand that maintaining a property can come with its challenges.

Given our mutual interest in ensuring a positive experience for both parties, we'd like to propose a solution that we believe benefits everyone involved. Considering the issues we've encountered, we believe it would be best for both of us if we could arrange a refund for the remainder of our stay and seek an alternative accommodation. This approach would allow us to find a more suitable place, and it would also prevent any negative impact on your Airbnb ratings or reviews. We genuinely believe you're a great host and we'd prefer not to leave a negative review for the property.

We understand that unforeseen issues can arise, and we're hopeful that this proposal aligns with your understanding of the situation. If you're open to discussing this further, please let us know the best way to proceed.

Thank you for your attention, and we look forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,

04/04/2024, 11:24 - Gracou: off the top of my head i would suggest the following:
1. I still don't see Bath as the best place to invest. It is expensive and planning permissions are really tight so it is difficult to make changes and improvements on the inside and outside of the property.
2. the house is quite ugly on the outside and doesnt tingle my spidey sense
3. i aim to have double bedrooms rather than single bedrooms, but these seem to be singles
4. students to not make the best tenants. they will trash the house so you will have to spend money fixing it each year. on top of this, every time a management company needs to refill your house with tenants, they tend to charge 1 months rent. So, as students usually move every year, over a ten year period that would take £13,000 out of your profit (based on the room rate you suggested). This would be considerably less for other kinds of tenants
5. most students do not find this a desirable place to live in and prefer oldfield park or the city centre. People that I know who lived up on the hill tended to pay less rent than the other places for this reason. So i dont think that you would get £650 for a single room there

02/11/2024, 15:03 - Gracou: Definitely the orange rice
06/11/2024, 11:40 - Théodore Bedos: For 2-3 portions

Ingredients:
- 2-3 chicken breasts
- 400g coconut milk (don't take light)
- 3 garlic gloves
- 40g of ginger (you can use easy ginger or ginger paste)
- 80g tomato puree
- 100-200g of baby spinach (normal spinach works too) (I put around 200 so that I have more veggies and it's more feeling, but the recipe says 120g I think)
- 1 chicken stock 
- Soya sauce 
- 1/2 lime
- Sesame oil

Instructions:

0- Start cooking your rice.

1- Finely chop the garlic and ginger, then dice the chicken.

2 - Eat a pan with sesame oil, once hot, add the chicken. Cook until not pink but not too cook (it's still going to cook a bit with the rest)

3 - add the garlic, the ginger and the tomato purée. Stir actively for 1 min.

4- add the Coco milk and the chicken stock paste. Let it boil and then reduce the heat and let it simmer for 5 min approx until you have a thicker consistency.

5 - Add the spinach a hand full at a time. Stir between each hand.

6- Add a the soya sauce. I don't know the quantity, I just zig zag over it once. Start with not too much, stir then taste and add more as you like.

7 - stop the heat. Squeeze the lemon juice.  And mix.

8 - Serve on the rice. You can  sprinkle some lemon zest on top but usually I am too lazy for it.

Enjoy

07/11/2024, 13:20 - Théodore Bedos: For 2-3 portions

Ingredients:
- 400-500g minced beef
- 200g fine green beans
- 3-4 schallots (depending if you have big or small ones)
- 3 garlic gloves
- 1/2 bottle ketjap Manis (in Sainsbury or Waitrose, I don't know about Asda)
- 1/4 small bottle of Soja sauce 
- Spring onions
- Coriander 
- sesame oil
- Rice 

Instructions:

0 - Start cooking rice

1- trim beans if needed, chop them in three

2 - finely chop garlic, finely slice shallots, slice Spring onions. Chope coriander roughly with the stems.

3- Heat sesame oil in pan. When fuming add beans. Stir actively for 2-3 mins until a bit burned almost. Then put them aside in a plate.

4 - Add mince beef and break it down actively. 

5 - When there is just a little bit of pink mince left, add the garlic and shallots. Stir until the shallots looks soft.

6 - Add ketjap Manis and soya sauce. Stir until weel mixed. 

7 - Add back the beans, and half the Spring onions (the whiter bits) and stir for 2 mins.

8 - Serve directly with the rice. Sprinkle left Spring onions and coriander on top.
